svMisc v1.5.2

Inject first argument in a call, usually data = (.)

Source: R/eval_data_dot.R
eval_data_dot.Rd

In case the data = (.) is missing in a call to a "data-dot" function (a function that defines that its first argument data= could be missing, and it this case, it is considered to be .), this function does the injection of the first argument in the call and evaluate it.

eval_data_dot(
  call,
  arg = "data",
  value = as.symbol("."),
  env = caller_env(2L),
  abort_msg = gettextf("Wrong '%s' argument.", arg),
  abort_msg2 = gettext("\nImplicit data-dot (.) not permitted"),
  abort_frame = caller_env()
)

Arguments

call

A call object, usually a function call.

arg

The name of the argument to inject, usually 'data' or '.data'.

value

The value to inject, usually the symbol '.'.

env

The environment where the evaluation of the data-dot-injected call should be evaluated (by default, caller_env(2L), should rarely be changed).

abort_msg

The message to use in case the 'data' argument is wrong.

abort_msg2

An additional message to append to the error message in case data-dot-injection is not permitted (when .SciViews.implicit.data.dot != TRUE)

abort_frame

The environment to use for the error message, by default, the caller environment (should rarely be changed).

Value

The result from evaluating the data-dot-injected call.

Details

The call is not checked if it is a correct function call. When called from within a function, passing sys.call() as call, it should be always correct.

Examples

# Here is how you create a data-dot function
my_subset <- function(data = (.), i, j) {
  if (!is.data.frame(data))
    return(eval_data_dot(sys.call()))

  # Code of the function
  # Second argument (i here) must not be a data.frame to avoid confusion
  data[i, j]
}
dtf1 <- data.frame(x = 1:3, y = 4:6)
my_subset(dtf1, 1, 'y')
#> [1] 4
# If data is in '.', it can be omitted
.= dtf1
my_subset(1, 'y')
#> [1] 4

# This mechanism is potentially confusing. You can inactivate it anywhere:
.SciViews.implicit.data.dot <- FALSE
# This time next call is wrong
#my_subset(1, 'y')
rm(.SciViews.implicit.data.dot) # Reactivate it
my_subset(1, 'y')
#> [1] 4
# Note that, if you have not defined '.' and try to use it, you got
# an error: uncomment next line to see it
#get_temp(".")
